title: Option to align files with folders and control indentation width in Explorer

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

In the File Explorer, the current indentation behavior has two limitations:
- Files and folders at the same level are not aligned horizontally (folders are slightly shifted compared to files).
- The indentation width between levels cannot be adjusted in a way that affects the Explorer tree consistently.

#Problems:
Visual inconsistency between files and folders makes directory structures harder to scan.
Some users prefer more or less indentation for readability, but the current workbench.tree.indent setting does not fully solve this for the Explorer.

#Proposal:
Add a setting (e.g., workbench.tree.alignFilesWithFolders) to ensure that files and folders at the same tree depth are aligned.
Improve or extend workbench.tree.indent so it reliably controls the horizontal indentation distance for each level in the Explorer tree.

Why this matters:
Consistent alignment improves readability and navigation in large projects.
Allowing users to customize indentation width supports accessibility and personal preference.
Makes the Explorer more flexible, on par with other editors and IDEs.

title: execute_prompt ignores mode and model in subprompts
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: Latest Pre-release
- VS Code Version: Insiders - Latest
- OS Version: Windows 11
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode):
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): All
- Logs:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write a prompt that uses execute_prompt to call another prompt.
2. The mode and model that are used to call the original prompt will be used to call the subprompt. The subprompt's model and model are not respected.

title: Claude Opus 4.1 in VS Code Copilot Chat returns “Sorry, no response was returned” but differs from meta issue #253126 (Claude Sonnet 4 works fine in the same environment)
body: This issue appears related to [#253126](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/253126) (chat-no-response) but differs in the following ways: Claude Sonnet 4 works fine in the same environment. Quota is still deducted despite the failed response. - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.31.2 - VS Code Version: 1.104.1 - OS Version: Windows 11 25H2 - Feature: ask mode - Selected model: Claude Opus 4.1 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open VS Code with GitHub Copilot Chat extension installed. 2. Sign in with a Copilot Pro+ account. 3. Select Claude Opus 4.1 from the model picker and confirm selection. 4. Enter a prompt that should return a multi‑paragraph answer. 5. Observe that the output is truncated and then displays “Sorry, no response was returned”. 6. Check quota usage — it decreases despite the failed response. Expected Behavior: Claude Opus 4.1 should return the full output without truncation or error, and failed responses should not consume quota. Actual Behavior: Output is truncated and then displays “Sorry, no response was returned”, and quota is still deducted. But Claude Sonnet 4 works fine in the same environment.

title: We should fetch models on account switch
body:
1. Be logged in VS Code with a GH Copilot with a Paid account. Notice how you get a lot of models in the dropdown
2. Log out, and login with a Free GH Copilot account
3. Notice that the model dropdown did not change 🐛  It changes on reload

Thus we should fetch and refresh model list on account login.

fyi @bpasero

Check quota usage — it decreases despite the failed response. Expected Behavior: Claude Opus 4.1 should return the full output without truncation or error, and failed responses should not consume quota. Actual Behavior: Output is truncated and then displays “Sorry, no response was returned”, and quota is still deducted. But Claude Sonnet 4 works fine in the same environment.

title: Fix PR links on SCM Graph hovers to point to upstream repo instead of fork
body:
Fixes an issue where PR and issue links in SCM Graph hover tooltips were pointing to the user's fork repository instead of the upstream repository, causing 404 errors when clicked.

## Problem

When users work with repository forks, commit messages containing PR/issue references like `#123` or `Fixes #456` were being converted to links pointing to the user's fork (e.g., `gjsjohnmurray/vscode/issues/123`) instead of the upstream repository where the actual PRs exist (e.g., `microsoft/vscode/issues/123`). This resulted in 404 errors when users clicked these links from SCM Graph hover tooltips.

The root cause was in `GitHubSourceControlHistoryItemDetailsProvider.provideMessageLinks()`, which used `getRepositoryDefaultRemote()` that prioritizes `origin` over `upstream` remotes. For fork workflows where `origin` points to the user's fork and `upstream` points to the original repository, this caused incorrect link generation.

## Solution

Added new utility functions that prioritize upstream remotes for PR/issue link generation:

- `getRepositoryUpstreamRemote()` - Returns repository info prioritizing upstream over origin
- `getRepositoryUpstreamRemoteUrl()` - Gets fetch URL using upstream priority logic

Updated `provideMessageLinks()` to use the new upstream-prioritized function instead of the default remote function. This aligns the behavior with the existing `openOnGitHub` command which already correctly prioritizes upstream remotes.

## Behavior Changes

**Before:**
- PR reference `#123` in commit message hover → `https://github.com/user-fork/repo/issues/123` (404 error)

**After:**  
- PR reference `#123` in commit message hover → `https://github.com/upstream-repo/repo/issues/123` (correct link)

**Fallback:**
- Repositories without upstream remotes continue to use origin as before

## Testing

Added unit tests verifying the upstream prioritization logic works correctly for repositories with various remote configurations (upstream + origin, origin only, etc.).

Closes #[issue-number]

title: `DocumentRangeSemanticTokensProvider` has no support for `onDidChangeSemanticTokens`
body:
In contrast to the `DocumentSemanticTokensProvider` the `DocumentRangeSemanticTokensProvider` has no support for `onDidChangeSemanticTokens`. To allow refreshing semantic tokens for ranges as well support for `onDidChangeSemanticTokens` is need.

Original reported against LSP via the CSharp team (see https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/issues/1672)

title: Add Copy Error Message to IntelliSense mouse hover tooltip
body: This is something you can already do in the "PROBLEMS" tab at the bottom of VSCode like so: But what's annoying is that there is no such button when hovering directly over the error in code: And trying to copy the error from this tooltip / popup window is very annoying and finicky: When I select it and Ctrl+C, it almost never works. I have to select it, wait a few seconds, Ctrl+C, wait a few seconds and then move my mouse away to be certain the text got copied and I can paste it into Google. It would be nice if it had the same Copy Error Message button right there on the hover or whatever is causing the direct select/copy of the text to be finicky was fixed. Or both.

title: Integrated terminal activates base conda environment instead of configured environment
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

**Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?**: No (This appears to be related to Python extension functionality)

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

- **VS Code Version**: 1.104.0
- **Node.js**: 22.18.0
- **OS Version**: Darwin x64 23.6.0, Sonoma 14.6.1 (23G93)

## Issue Description

VS Code fails to automatically activate the correct conda environment in integrated terminal despite `python.terminal.activateEnvironment: true` setting and correct Python interpreter configuration.

## Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install conda/miniconda and create a conda environment (e.g., `conda create -n node-dev python=3.x`)
2. Open VS Code and create a new workspace/project
3. Configure workspace settings:
   ```json
   {
       "python.defaultInterpreterPath": "/Users/[username]/miniconda3/envs/node-dev/bin/python",
       "python.condaPath": "/Users/[username]/miniconda3/bin/conda",
       "python.terminal.activateEnvironment": true,
       "terminal.integrated.inheritEnv": false
   }
   ```
4. Verify the correct Python interpreter is selected (should show in status bar)
5. Open a new integrated terminal (`Cmd+``)
6. Observe the terminal prompt and run `echo $CONDA_DEFAULT_ENV`

## Expected Result:
- Terminal should show `(node-dev)` in prompt
- `echo $CONDA_DEFAULT_ENV` should output `node-dev`
- VS Code should automatically activate the conda environment specified by the Python interpreter

## Actual Result:
- Terminal shows `(base)` in prompt (or no environment activated)
- `echo $CONDA_DEFAULT_ENV` outputs `base` (or empty)
- The base conda environment is activated instead of the configured one
- Manual `conda activate node-dev` works correctly

## Additional Information:

**Environment Details:**
- Shell: zsh (default on macOS)
- Conda properly initialized in `.zshrc`
- `which conda` returns a shell function (normal conda setup)
- Python extension correctly identifies the interpreter (visible in status bar)

**Configuration Files:**
```json
// Workspace settings
{
    "python.defaultInterpreterPath": "/Users/tony/miniconda3/envs/node-dev/bin/python",
    "python.condaPath": "/Users/tony/miniconda3/bin/conda",
    "python.terminal.activateEnvironment": true,
    "terminal.integrated.inheritEnv": false
}
```

**Workaround that works:**
Creating a custom terminal profile manually activates the correct environment:
```json
{
    "terminal.integrated.defaultProfile.osx": "conda-env",
    "terminal.integrated.profiles.osx": {
        "conda-env": {
            "path": "/bin/zsh",
            "args": ["-l", "-c", "conda activate node-dev; exec zsh"]
        }
    }
}
```

However, this shouldn't be necessary when `python.terminal.activateEnvironment: true` is configured.

**Tested scenarios:**
- ✅ Custom terminal profile with manual conda activate
- ❌ `python.terminal.activateEnvironment: true` (should work but doesn't)
- ❌ Various `terminal.integrated.env.osx` configurations
- ✅ Manual activation after terminal opens

This issue affects productivity as developers need to manually activate the correct environment every time they open a new terminal, despite having the correct configuration.

title: Add API / command for showing a specific local chat session
body:
From an extension, I'd like the ability to create a new chat session and then restore that same chat session in the UI at a later point

Right now I'm using `workbench.action.chat.newChat` and  `workbench.action.chat.open` command. With these commands, I'd like to be able to so something like this:

- Call `workbench.action.chat.newChat` with an unique id for the chat session 
- Later call `workbench.action.chat.open` with that same id to restore the previous session 

---

This seems related to the chat sessions API but that API is almost all provider side right now. We haven't thought much about how extensions can interact with chat sessions

title: Hook up ChatResponseDataPart to chat output renderers
body:
## Hook up LanguageModelDataPart to chat output renderers ✅

This PR enables extensions to render custom content directly in chat responses using the existing `LanguageModelDataPart`, without requiring tool calls or new APIs. Extensions can now generate content like diagrams, visualizations, or other custom formats that will be rendered through the existing chat output renderer system.

### Implementation:
- [x] Explore existing architecture and understand how content parts work
- [x] Add data part support to chat content types (`IChatProgressHistoryResponseContent`)  
- [x] Add data part content handling in chat list renderer (`renderChatContentPart`)
- [x] Create new chat data content part component that uses chat output renderers
- [x] Add complete type converter support for `LanguageModelDataPart` → `IChatDataContent`
- [x] Use existing `LanguageModelDataPart` class without creating new APIs
- [x] Fix all compilation errors and type issues
- [x] Remove unauthorized changes to main vscode.d.ts API
- [x] Follow feedback to avoid creating unnecessary new APIs

### Key Components Added:
- ✅ **`IChatDataContent`** - new interface for data parts in chat progress
- ✅ **`ChatDataContentPart`** - renders data parts using `IChatOutputRendererService`  
- ✅ **Type converter** - converts `LanguageModelDataPart` to `IChatDataContent`
- ✅ **Data part handling** in `ChatListRenderer.renderChatContentPart`

### API Usage:
Extensions can now render custom content directly in chat responses using the existing `LanguageModelDataPart` with the standard `push()` method:

```ts
// In a chat participant handler (requires both chatParticipantAdditions and languageModelDataPart proposed APIs)
response.push(new vscode.LanguageModelDataPart(encodedMermaidText, 'text/vnd.mermaid'));
```

This will automatically:
1. Convert the data to `IChatDataContent`
2. Find the appropriate chat output renderer for the MIME type
3. Render the content using the renderer (e.g., mermaid diagram)

### Benefits:
- ✅ **Direct rendering** without requiring tool calls
- ✅ **No new APIs** - uses existing `LanguageModelDataPart` class
- ✅ **Type safety** with full TypeScript support
- ✅ **Extensible** - works with any registered chat output renderer
- ✅ **Compatible** with existing tool-based approach
- ✅ **Proper API boundaries** - leverages existing proposed API infrastructure
- ✅ **Follows feedback** - avoids creating unnecessary new APIs

### Technical Implementation:
The conversion flow works as follows:
1. **Extension calls** `response.push(new LanguageModelDataPart(data, mimeType))` (existing API)
2. **Type converter** detects `LanguageModelDataPart` and creates `IChatDataContent` progress part
3. **Chat renderer** creates `ChatDataContentPart` 
4. **Output renderer service** finds appropriate renderer and renders content
5. **UI displays** custom rendered content inline with chat response

This enables extensions like the mermaid chat features to generate content directly without requiring tool invocations, making the chat experience more seamless and responsive, while respecting API boundaries and reusing existing infrastructure.

Fixes microsoft/vscode#266124

  can be activated lazily and specifically.

Closes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/266221

title: Chaining mode tasks using @mode_name in prompt
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Prerequisite: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/268095

I want to create chained AI agent workflows for end-to-end tasks like "build website from Figma/screenshot." Each agent handles one job and creates context handoffs for the next agent.
Example workflow:

Screenshot Analyzer → analysis doc → 
Design Tokenizer → tokens.css & preview HTML → 
BaseUI Builder → component library & usage docs → 
Site Builder → final site + Playwright test report

Request: Enable calling @mode_agent from within other mode agents to structure handoffs and pass context between them.

title: Use @mode_name to specify your mode.
body: When writing up agent mode instructions, I would like to be able to @mention other modes and send that agent context. I currently have 12 modes that I set up for myself, but anticipate have many others as time goes on. Currently the only way switch my modes is via a drop down, but that is already a bit confusing because I think of my modes as squads that sequentailly run workflows for me, so I find myself click on the drop and searching for names a lot. I would love if we could expand the @mentions to go beyond just extension like @workspace, @vscode, etc, and also include modes.

title: Feature/107183 add ability to right align tree items description
body:
Issue #107183: Add a new right-aligned "description" property to TreeItems

Added the ability for VS Code extensions utilizing the [`TreeView`](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/extension-guides/tree-view) to horizontally align the `description` property of `TreeItems` to the right. Default value remains left-aligned.

## How to Test
1. Clone the [vscode-extension-samples](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-extension-samples) project
2. Open the [`tree-view-sample`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/tree/main/tree-view-sample) in Code
3. Open [`src/nodeDependencies.ts#`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/blob/main/tree-view-sample/src/nodeDependencies.ts#L98)
4. Add a new line right below where the `TreeItem.description` is being set
    > this.alignment = 'right';`

    *(since the repo references a released version of the vscode api you will want to also add an `// @ts-ignore` right about it just for testing)*
5. Run the extension as usual
6. Open any repo utilizing npm (I just created a new folder and ran `> npm i three`
7. Click on the new list clover in the left-hand sidebar that the extension added
8. Expand the tree and all the package versions will now be aligned to the right

Since `TreeItem` actions appear to the right, the description will hide any-time they show as to not clash.

title: chatSessions API redesign/experiment
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

Experiment for https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/268063
Demo extension implementation: https://github.com/joshspicer/joshbot/

- Do not dynamically register chat participant (let extension do that)
- Lean more on existing chat participant API
- Introduce concept of 'untitled' chat session
- `onDidCreateChatSessionItem` to swap untitled sessions -> backed sessions

This change is NOT backward-compatible since we will not longer register the chat participant implementation dynamically. The implementing extension should now register the participant.

This lets us delete `provideNewChatSessionItem`, but I will remove that in a follow up

title: Update the extensionApi embeddings to use metis instead of textsmall
body: Same as #268074 but of the extension API flow

title: Switch git related files to use metis embeddings

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: scm
labels.description: General SCM compound issues

body:
Same as https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/268074 but for related files. Actually should be simpler since there's no global cache

The new metis embeddings should provide better results than text3small and are more efficient to work with. This item tracks switching the `GitRelatedFilesProvider` to use metis


I quickly reviewed the code and think this may be as simple as changing the `EmbeddingType` passed to `computeEmbeddings`. However I'd like someone with more familiarity with the code to test this

One other note for this item: you can actually much better results if you use the `inputType` option for computing embeddings. The text you are searching should use `document`, while the search string should use `query`:


```ts
const promptEmbeddings = await this._embeddingsComputer.computeEmbeddings(EmbeddingType.metis_1024_I16_Binary, [prompt], { inputType: 'query' }, new TelemetryCorrelationId('GitRelatedFilesProvider::computeCommitMessageEmbeddings'), token);

const commitEmbeddings = await this._embeddingsComputer.computeEmbeddings(EmbeddingType.metis_1024_I16_Binary, commitMessages, { inputType: 'document' }, new TelemetryCorrelationId('GitRelatedFilesProvider::computeCommitMessageEmbeddings'), token);
```

title: Switch newWorkspace to use metis instead of text3small for searching the project template index
body:
Same as #268074 but for newWorkspace and the project template index

Metis should provide higher quality results and is more efficient. Let's try migrating  `newWorkspace` and the project template index over to use it instead of text3small

title: Update command and setting embedding caches to use metis
body:
The command and setting embedding indexes currently use text3small. We should be good to switch these over the use metis embeddings, which has better quality and a smaller size

This involves:
-  Update our remote embedding caches for these to also publish metis embeddings
- Switch our code in copilot chat over to use metis. This should be as simple as replacing `EmbeddingType.text3small_512` with `EmbeddingType.metis_1024_I16_Binary`once the `ICombinedEmbeddingIndex` has been updated to support metis

- VS Code Version:
  - Version: 1.104.1 (Universal)
  - Commit: 0f0d87fa9e96c856c5212fc86db137ac0d783365
  - Date: 2025-09-17T23:36:24.973Z
  - Electron: 37.3.1
  - ElectronBuildId: 12404162
  - Chromium: 138.0.7204.235
  - Node.js: 22.18.0
  - V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0
  - OS: Darwin arm64 24.6.0
- OS Version: macOS 15.6.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch VS Code
2. “GitHub Copilot app modernization” plugin is suddenly installed…
3. …and is asking for some kind of shady GitHub authorization??
4. Extension has to be manually uninstalled.

AFAICT, this plugin is utterly irrelevant to my work: I don’t use .NET or Azure, and don’t want this product.

Was this just a deployment screw-up? Or is VS Code now sending me in-app spam?

title: Set suppressInSnippetMode default to true to prevent inline completions from interfering with snippets
body:
Fixes #254275

## Summary

Changes the default value of `editor.inlineSuggest.suppressInSnippetMode` from `false` to `true` to prevent inline completions (like Copilot) from interfering with snippet workflows.

## Problem

Users reported that inline completions constantly interrupt snippet workflows, causing the following issues:

- Pressing `Tab` to navigate between snippet placeholders would accidentally accept inline completions instead
- The `editor.suggest.snippetsPreventQuickSuggestions` setting was being ignored
- Snippet workflows were frequently broken by completion suggestions appearing at inappropriate times
- Users had to constantly toggle Copilot on/off or manually configure settings to work around the issue

## Solution

The fix changes the default behavior to suppress inline completions when users are actively working within snippets. This aligns with user expectations that snippet navigation should take precedence over completion suggestions.

**Before:** `suppressInSnippetMode: false` (inline completions show during snippet mode)
**After:** `suppressInSnippetMode: true` (inline completions suppressed during snippet mode)

## Impact

- **Improved UX**: Snippet workflows will no longer be interrupted by inline completions by default
- **Backward Compatible**: Users who prefer the old behavior can manually set `editor.inlineSuggest.suppressInSnippetMode: false`
- **Minimal Risk**: Single line change with existing suppression logic already in place
- **Addresses Core Issue**: Directly resolves the interference between snippets and inline completions

The existing logic in `InlineCompletionsModel` already handles this suppression correctly - when both `suppressInSnippetMode` and `isInSnippetMode` are true, it returns `undefined` to suppress completions.

## Testing

- ✅ Compilation successful with 0 errors
- ✅ Validated default value change is correctly applied
- ✅ Confirmed suppression logic works as expected
- ✅ No breaking changes to existing functionality

title: Improve Accessibility of Copilot Chat with an Integrated Accessible Mode
body: Type: Feature Request --- **Title:** Improve Accessibility of Copilot Chat with an Integrated Accessible Mode **Subtitle:** Eliminate reliance on external workarounds (files, scripts, strict rules) by providing structured navigation, reliable transcripts, subtle status updates, and configurable accessible view settings for screen reader users. --- ### Problem to be Solved Many blind and low-vision developers cannot rely on Copilot’s built-in chat interface. The accessible view is disruptive to switch in and out of, and often fails to render all communication, leaving users unsure of what took place. As a result, developers have built their own accessibility protocols: * Redirecting every Copilot response into a text file (`chat.txt`). * Using scripts to open that file in Notepad since it works better with NVDA/JAWS. * Enforcing “don’t act until you see ‘go’” rules to avoid unintended actions. * Running custom scripts that announce task status with audio cues, because Copilot’s “Working…” messages are verbose and disruptive. These workarounds prove that the current UI isn’t meeting accessibility needs, but they also show what users value: reliability, clear context, and trustworthy feedback. --- ### TL;DR Copilot Chat forces blind/low-vision developers into external hacks (files, scripts, rules) to make it usable. We propose an **Accessible Mode** with structured navigation, reliable transcript handling, subtle status updates, and a configurable **Accessible View Prompt file/setting** so screen reader users can stay fully productive inside VS Code. --- ### Proposed Solution **1. Structured Chat View** * Add **ARIA roles, headings, and landmarks** so each chat turn is distinguishable. * Make code blocks, links, and buttons **properly labeled and interactive**. **2. Accessible Transcript Panel** * Provide a built-in **linear transcript buffer** (like `chat.txt`) for reviewing, editing, and replying. * Support **carry-forward context** with clear boundaries between task phases. **3. Status Feedback** * Replace verbose “Working…” messages with concise **ARIA live region updates** or subtle **audio cues**. * Allow optional hooks for custom feedback integrations. **4. Reliability & Safeguards** * Add a **confirmation mode** so Copilot won’t act until explicitly approved (“go”). * Support **optional auto-clear/overwrite cycles**: * When enabled, transcript clears before each new response to prevent clutter. * When disabled, responses append with **heading markers** so prior exchanges remain navigable for backward review. **5. Accessible View Improvements** * Ensure **all communication is preserved** when switching in/out of accessible view. * Provide a **configurable Accessible View Prompt file/setting** so users can define what content (summaries, code, metadata) is always shown. **6. Experimental Mode** * Ship all of the above behind a **feature flag** (“Accessible Mode for Copilot Chat”) for iterative testing with the community. --- ### Acceptance Criteria (Success Conditions) 1. **Structured Chat View** * Chat turns are navigable by screen reader via heading-level navigation. * Code blocks, links, and buttons are labeled interactive elements. 2. **Accessible Transcript Panel** * Transcript can be reviewed and replied to inside VS Code without external files. * Supports both read-only review and editable reply. 3. **Status Feedback** * “Working…” replaced with concise live region or audio cue updates. * Users can enable/disable audio or custom hooks. 4. **Reliability & Safeguards** * Confirmation mode prevents actions until explicitly approved. * Auto-clear/overwrite cycles are **optional**; appended responses use headings for structured review. 5. **Accessible View Improvements** * Switching accessible view preserves all prior communication. * Accessible View Prompt file/setting determines which content is always rendered. 6. **Experimental Mode** * Features toggleable via a feature flag for testing. ✅ Meeting these conditions ensures Copilot Chat delivers a first-class, inclusive experience for blind and low-vision developers, without requiring external hacks. --- ### Additional Context This request is based on **real-world developer experience**. To make Copilot usable, blind/low-vision users have already invented parallel systems (files, scripts, strict rules). These are powerful indicators of unmet needs and a blueprint for improvement. By embedding these accessibility practices directly into Copilot, GitHub can reduce friction, provide trust, and deliver on inclusive design principles. --- VS Code version: Code 1.104.1 (0f0d87fa9e96c856c5212fc86db137ac0d783365, 2025-09-17T23:36:24.973Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: Please allow a seeting for time before making suggestions
body: Type: Feature Request It can be really distracting when you are trying to complete a thought and copilot is jumping in with it's own ideas of what you are after. I'd love it if you added a setting where users can choose to put a delay prior to having the copilot suggestion. title: Chat Session API proposal: integrate with chat participants and handle new chat session creation
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

We have adopted the Chat Session API for both the GitHub Coding Agent and the Claude Code. The API supports listing all existing chat sessions and initiating new ones. While adopting the API, we learned that the current API design works well for listing sessions but falls short for creating new sessions. One challenge we faced was that chat request handling and chat session item-to-content mapping are deeply coupled, making it difficult to build the right mental model for using the two providers.

Today in the API meeting, we brainstormed ways to decouple these components and whether we could take inspiration from the controller-style API (e.g., the Commenting API). Here is a proposal based on our conversation.

```ts
export interface ChatSessionItemProvider {
	readonly onDidChangeChatSessionItems: Event<void>;
	readonly onDidChangeChatSessionContent: Event<ChatSessionItem>;
	provideChatSessionItems(token: CancellationToken): ProviderResult<ChatSessionItem[]>;
	resolveChatSessionContent(sessionItem: ChatSessionItem, token: CancellationToken): AsyncIterable<ChatRequestTurn | ChatResponseTurn2 | ExtendedChatResponsePart>;
}

export interface ChatSessionCapabilities {
	supportsInterruptions?: boolean;
}

export interface ChatSessionController {
	readonly sessionType: string;
	readonly chatParticipant: ChatParticipant;
	readonly chatSessionCapabilities: ChatSessionCapabilities;
	chatSessionItemProvider?: ChatSessionItemProvider;
	newChatSessionHandler?: (request: ChatRequest, metadata: any, token: CancellationToken) => ProviderResult<ChatSessionItem>;
}

export interface ChatContext {
	readonly chatSession: ChatSessionItem;
}

namespace chat {
	export function createChatSessionController(sessionType: string, chatParticipant: ChatParticipant, chatSessionCapabilities: ChatSessionCapabilities): ChatSessionController;
}
```

The new proposal splits the functionalities into the following pieces:

- Extensions contribute a chat session controller to register functionalities.
- Extensions can register a chat session item provider to list and resolve chat sessions.
	- The Chat Session View uses the provider to list all existing sessions; it's meant to be lightweight and fast.
	- When a user opens a chat session, the view calls `resolveChatSessionContent` to load the session's content. This content is an asynchronous iterable consisting of request turn, response turn, or response parts if the response is incomplete and still streaming. Once complete, the iterable finishes.
- Extensions contribute a chat participant to handle chat requests, whether they are new requests from the sidebar chat or followups (secondary turns) in a chat session editor. `ChatContext#chatSession` provides the current session item, which can be `undefined` for new requests.
- Extensions can optionally provide a newChatSessionHandler to create a new chat session item when a new chat request is made. The core will resolve its content later.
